title-group.article-title: Bioremoval of heavy metals from industrial effluent by fixed-bed column of red macroalgae

article-meta.aff: 2Biology Department, Umm Al-Qura University, Makkah, Saudi Arabia

author-notes.corresp: Hawazin H Mutawie, Biology Department, Umm Al-Qura University, Makkah 715, Saudi Arabia. Email: mutawie@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Three different species of nonliving red algal biomass Laurancia obtusa, Geldiella acerosa and Hypnea sp. were used to build three types of fixed-bed column for the removal of toxic heavy metal ions such as Cu2+, Zn2+, Mn2+ and Ni2+ from industrial effluent. In general, the highest efficiency of metal ion bioremoval was recorded for algal column of L. obtusa followed by G. acerosa and the lowest one was recorded for Hypnea sp., with mean removal values of 94%, 85% and 71%, respectively. The obtained results showed that biological treatments of industrial effluents with these algal columns, using standard algal biotest, Pseudokirchneriella subcapitata, were capable of reducing effluent toxicities from 75% to 15%, respectively. Red algal column may be considered as an inexpensive and efficient alternative treatment for conventional removal technology, for sequestering heavy metal ions from industrial effluents.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Pollution by heavy metal ions is one of the major environmental problems in many countries as metal ions in potable waters and waste waters in many cases exceed the admissible sanitary standards. Aqueous effluents emanating from many industries contain dissolved heavy metals. If these discharges are emitted without treatment, they may have an adverse impact on the environment (Herrero et al., 2006). Heavy metals are not biodegradable and tend to accumulate in living organisms causing various diseases and disorders as well as deleterious ecological effects (Loutseti et al., 2009).

Conventional methods for removing metals are either becoming inadequate to address current stringent regulatory effluent limits or increasing in cost. As a result, alternative, inexpensive and effective technologies are in high demand. The use of biological materials, including living and nonliving microorganisms, to remove and recover toxic or precious metals from industrial waste waters has gained popularity over the years due to good performance, availability and low cost of raw materials (Bunluesin et al., 2007).

Different biomasses can effectively uptake heavy metals, but recent research has shown that marine algae are more effective than other biological materials (Romera et al., 2006). An additional advantage is that algae especially brown (Phaeophyta) and red (Rhodophyta) grow exclusively in salt water (Romera et al., 2008). Red seaweeds possess a high metal-binding capacity (Ibrahim, 2011) due to the presence of various functional groups such as carboxyl, amino, sulphate and hydroxyl groups in the cell wall, which can act as binding sites for metal ions (Murphy et al., 2007).

Pseudokirchneriella subcapitata (formerly known as Selenastrum capricornutum and Rhapidocelis subcapitata) is considered a model organism and is widely used in the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) algal growth inhibition test as well as in US Environmental Protection Agency green algae growth inhibition test (US Environmental Protection Agency, 1996). This species has also proven to be very sensitive to heavy metals (Blinova, 2004; Kahru et al., 2005).

The objective of the present study is to evaluate the efficiency of dried red macroalgal column for removing and recovering heavy metals from contaminated industrial effluent through continuous system.

sec.title: Preparation of algal powder
sec.p: The red algae Laurancia obtusa, Geldiella acerosa and Hypnea sp. were collected in May and June 2011 from Red Sea on the coast of Hurghada, Egypt. The algae were washed with tap water and then distilled water several times to remove impurities. The washed algae were then completely dried in sunlight for 10 days. The dried algae were cut into small pieces and were powdered using a mixer. The powdered materials were sieved to obtain 1–2 mm particles, then directly used as adsorbents.

sec.title: Industrial effluent sampling
sec.p: The industrial effluent of Talkha factory (Dakahlia, Egypt) for chemical fertilizers was chosen to investigate the efficiency of algal biofilters to remove heavy metal ions. Composite effluent samples were collected, during working hours of the factories, in polyethylene containers from their outfalls. Effluent samples were thoroughly mixed; 6 L were filtered through glass microfiber filters, size 1-2 µm (GF/C), Whatman glass filters. The first 1 L of the filtrate was discarded and the remaining 5 L were stored at 4°C in dark to be used for chemical and toxicity assessment analysis.

The hydrogen ion activity of the GF/C filtered industrial effluent was adjusted to pH 6.0 (optimum pH for heavy metal bioremoval; Azab et al., 2008). pH-adjusted effluent was passed through different types of algal columns.

sec.title: Column experiments
sec.p: A glass column of 30 cm height and 1.8 cm internal diameter (Figure 1) was used to carry out the column studies. Individual columns were packed with 5 g of individual algal powders. The pH-adjusted effluent flow was pumped up through the bed using a peristaltic pump connected at the bottom of the column. Experiments were carried out at the flow rate of 15 ml min−1 (Lodeiro et al., 2006). Samples of the biologically treated effluents were filtered through GF/C Whatman glass filters in order to separate the dissolved fraction from possible suspension material that could influence the heavy metal measurements. The filtrate was subjected to toxicity assessment and metal ion analysis.

caption.p: Experimental arrangement of the removal packed bed column. (1) pH-adjusted effluent, (2) peristaltic pump, (3) valve, (4) flow meter, (5) column, (6) bottom sieve, (7) packed algal powder, (8) top sieve and (9) algal-treated effluent.

sec.title: Determination of heavy metals
sec.p: The heavy metals in raw and biologically treated effluents were measured as described by APHA (1989). Acidified filtered samples were analyzed for metal concentrations using Perkin-Elmer atomic absorption spectrophotometer Model 2380.

sec.title: Toxicity assessment of untreated and treated industrial effluents
sec.p: The methods described by Porcella (1983), Greene et al. (1989) and Koukal et al. (2003) were adopted to carry out the toxicity test of GF/C-filtered industrial effluent, pH-adjusted effluent and biologically treated effluent. Growth inhibition test with P. subcapitata (Norwegian Institute for Water Research culture collection chlorophyceae number 1) was performed in algal medium according to the OECD guideline for testing of chemicals No. 201 (OECD, 2006). The initial algal density of 5 × 106 cells L−1 was incubated for 5 days at 25 ± 1°C under continuous illumination (approximately 4000 Lux) provided by cool white fluorescent tubes. Cell count was determined at the end of incubation period using a standard hemocytometer.

EC50 and SC20 express the minimum effluent concentrations inhibiting and stimulating the algal growth by 50% and 20%, respectively.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: Data were presented as mean replicates from three runs and were analyzed statistically using Student’s t test for independent samples. Statements of significant differences were based on accepting p ≤ 0.05 according to SPSS (1999).

sec.title: Chemical characteristics of effluents
sec.p: The chemical properties of Talkha chemical fertilizers factory are given in Table 1. The effluent of Talkha chemical fertilizers was alkaline with the pH 10.12. Analysis of heavy metal ions revealed that the concentration of effluent metal ions varied from 0.75 mg L−1 to 0.95 mg L−1.

caption.p: Some chemical properties of the investigated industrial effluent.

sec.title: Efficiency of algal column to remove metal ions from industrial effluent
sec.p: The efficiency of algal column to remove metal ions from industrial effluent varied from one metal to another, this variation was to some extent dependent on the metal ion and the algal biomass (Figure 2). The efficiency of algal column to remove different metal ions ranged between 43.6% and 98%. Algal columns were capable of completely removing Cu and Zn from the industrial effluent. In general, the highest efficiency of metal ion bioremoval was recorded for algal column of L. obtusa followed by G. acerosa and the lowest one was recorded for that of Hypnea sp. with mean removal values of 94%, 85% and 71%, respectively (Figure 2).

caption.p: Bioremoval of different heavy metal ions from the chemical fertilizers’ effluent of Talkha factory.

sec.title: Toxicity assessment of untreated and treated industrial effluents
sec.p: It was generally noticed that the values of EC50 of pH-adjusted effluent subsamples were significantly (p ≤ 0.05) higher (lower toxicity) compared to the corresponding values of raw effluent samples (Figures 3 and 4). The Talkha chemical fertilizers’ effluent was relatively toxic, as low effluent concentration exhibited strong growth inhibition of the test alga (Figure 3) with EC50 of 3.1%. Adjustment of pH of Talkha effluent resulted in a marked decrease in its toxicity (EC50 = 15%).

caption.p: Dose–response curves of Pseudokirchneriella subcapitata grown for 5 days at different concentrations of Talkha chemical fertilizer effluent.
Efficiency of algal column to reduce the toxicity of Talkha chemical fertilizers’ effluent.

sec.p: Algal-treated samples of Talkha chemical fertilizers’ effluent induced marginal algal growth stimulation at very low concentration (below 0.1% v/v) beyond which all concentration levels were growth inhibitory. Biological treatment of Talkha chemical fertilizers’ effluent with different algal column reduced its toxicity as EC50 values were significantly (p ≤ 0.05) increased from 15% to 75.4% (Figure 3). Moreover, the calculated % toxicity reduction ranged between minimum and maximum values of 162% and 273% (Table 2).

caption.p: Percentage of toxicity reduction of algal columns for Talkha chemical fertilizers’ effluent

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The efficiency of algal columns to remove different heavy metals from industrial effluent is in agreement with those of Ibrahim (2011) who investigated the ability of Corallina mediterranea, Galaxaura oblongata, Jania rubens and Pterocladia capillacea biomasses to remove Co, Cd, Cr and Pb ions from El-Fayoum for chemical production company effluent for two biosorption–elution cycles. He found that the efficiencies of red algal biomasses to remove metal ions ranged from 57% to 94%. Also Sari and Tuzen (2008) investigated the efficiency of Ceramium virgatum biomass to remove Cd ions at different pH values. They found that the high biosorption efficiency (94%) was obtained at pH 6. The high metal uptake capacity of red algal biomass may be due to the presence of high content of carboxyl groups from mannuronic and guluronic acids on the cell wall polysaccharides, which can act as binding sites for heavy metal ions (Matheickal and Yu, 1999).

The high concentration of toxic heavy metal ions in raw industrial effluents probably inhibited the growth of test alga P. subcapitata. Removal of different heavy metal ions from industrial effluents by red algal columns induced noticeable increase in the growth of standard test alga which could be considered as increasing in EC50 and percentage of toxicity reduction.

The toxic effect of different heavy metal ions on the standard test alga (Figures 3 and 4) was pointed out by Lavoie et al. (2009) who reported that P. subcapitata was more sensitive to Cd exposure with an EC50 of 273 nM Cd2+. Aruoja et al. (2009) determined the toxicities of ZnO, CuO and TiO2 on P. subcapitata using OECD 201 algal growth inhibition test. Moreover, the toxicity of mixtures of heavy metals was evaluated using the alga P. subcapitata as test organism by Angerville et al. (2008). They found that the interactions between different heavy metals significantly increase their toxic effect against P. subcapitata.

It is concluded from the present study that marine red algal powder could be used for the bioremoval of different heavy metal ions from industrial effluents and is also capable, in some cases, to fully remove effluent toxicity. The experimental results demonstrated that these red seaweeds constitute a promising, efficient and cheap biomaterial for heavy metals removal from waste waters. This would represent an example of exploitation of a renewable marine resource in water treatment technologies for the lowering of heavy metal pollution in the environment.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
